Key Match Events: Shohei Ohtani hit a three-run home run in the eighth inning
The Mets managed only four hits (all were singles) against Walker Buehler and the Dodgers bullpen in getting shut out for the second time in three games
Tylor Megill allowed two unearned runs over 4 ²/₃ innings
Freddie Freeman’s two-out single in the fifth and a walk to Muncy gave the Dodgers a threat
Kiké Hernández hit a two-run home run in the sixth
Will Smith’s single off Severino’s glove brought in the game’s first run
Ryan Brasier induced a ground into an inning-ending double play
Pre-Game Insights: We play the game to try to give a good show for [the fans],” Francisco Lindor said. “And we didn’t do anything to give them moments. They didn’t get what they came here to see.
The challenge won’t get any easier on Thursday, when Dodgers ace Yoshinobu Yamamoto is scheduled to face Jose Quintana in Game 4.
Post-Match Reflections: The guys that are in there got us to this point,” Mendoza said. “And I’m pretty confident they will come through.
We got beat 9-0 the first game and came back and won,” Garrett said. “I don’t see any reason why we can’t do that [Thursday].
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Mets scored two unearned runs in the second after Alvarez’s throwing error to second base
The Mets loaded the bases in the bottom of the third but escaped by retiring Hernandez and Lux in succession
Marte’s single in the sixth against Ryan Brasier and Martinez’s walk created a buzz from the fans, but Iglesias quashed it fast by grounding into an inning-ending double play
Walker Buehler allowed two unearned runs over four shutout innings with six strikeouts
The Mets’ pitching struggled, allowing three hits and two walks over four shutout innings
